title: How is kinetic energy and force related? - Quora

response.answer_text: Kinetic Energy & Force are essentially unrelated! That being said, in the evolution of the motion of an object (which we simplify as a "particle"), the Kinetic Energy and the Force may be viewed as related temporarily (relateable/associated in time) in some cases but are totally different physical concepts. Example 1: Consider a particle moving horizontally in a straight line (simple one dimensional motion) with a constant external force while staying at the same altitude. Absent any form of friction or drag, the speed will increase iff (if & only if) the force applied is in the same direction as the speed. Since the Kinetic Energy goes like (is proportional to) the speed squared, the Kinetic Energy will increase quadratically as the distance increases linearly (the force does work on the system by increasing the system's Kinetic Energy). Example 2: Consider a particle moving vertically in a straight line (simple one dimensional motion) with a constant speed while a constant external upward force is applied staying a the same altitude. Absent any form of friction or drag, the altitude will increase at a constant rate (speed) iff (if & only if) the force applied is upward and equals the force of gravity (the weight). Since the Kinetic Energy goes like (is proportional to) the speed squared, the Kinetic Energy will be constant while the Potential Energy will increase linearly as the distance increases linearly (the force still does work on the system by increasing the system's Potential Energy ). As said at the beginning, Kinetic Energy & Force are essentially unrelated and that's because they are totally different physical concepts.

The relationship between Kinetic Energy (KE) and force (F) can be seen by looking at the relationship between several basic equations. First, Kinetic Energy is proportional to the square of the velocity (v): KE = 0.5 * m * v^2 For example, whatever mass (m) happens to be, if the velocity doubles, the KE goes up by a factor of 4. The next equation is one that relates a change in velocity to acceleration (a): v = a * t, where t is time (usually in second). For example, if something accelerates at a constant rate of 1 meter per second per second, after 10 seconds, it would be moving at a velocity of 10 meters per second. The final equation is perhaps Newton’s most easily recognized equation F = ma, or Force = mass * acceleration This shows the direct proportional relationship between Force, mass, and acceleration. As an example, if the force is acting on a mass is doubled, the acceleration is also doubled. From these, we can see that a change in force affects acceleration, which affects velocity. So, for a given amount of mass and time, we can see that Kinetic Energy is proportional to the square of the Force applied.
